fields.title: AAAAAARGH!!
fields.short_description: AAAARGH! is a loud single computer local massive multiplayer racing game for 4 – n players. The game can be played on any computer without any special equipment. The goal was to expand the game experience to as many players as possible without having the players to use the keyboard or any special hardware. The game should be easily accessible and so it is. The game mechanic and the player input is sound. A lot of sound. Hence the name of the game. Basically the game is about yelling as loud as possible when you colour lights up.

fields.title: Photonboy
fields.short_credits: Lasse Jon Fuglsang Pedersen, Tim Garbos and Peter Bruun-Rasmussen (audio programming)
fields.short_description:
hotonboy is an abstract game where you as the player undertake the quest of photonboy. The world is only experienced through sending millions of photons out into the world. A world where space itself is relative. You are perceiving the world from the perspective of photonboy and only see what can be iluminated by the photons from its position.

To create the game, a custom rendering engine was made. This was done at the Exile Indie Game Jam of spring 2012 in about 48 hours.

fields.title: IDIOTS ATTACK THE TOP NOODLE
fields.short_credits: Anders Børup (sound and music), Simon Wallner, Amani Naseem, Ida Marie Toft, Julian Hansen and Patrick Jarnfelt
fields.short_description:
“What do we want!?”
“braaain…”
“When do we want it!?″
“braaain…”

Story:

In a not so distant future, the Idiots have overpopulated the world by breeding uncontrollably, while the intellectuals have diminished in numbers to a small group of elites, called the Brains. The idiots have found out, that while the elite group is smaller in numbers, they still have control over the general population with intricate use of their power of intelligence to rule over the Idiots. The Idiots realizing that they have been mind controlled by a small group of elites, revolt and fight, to take back the power, and try to overthrow the Brains. But they are subject to the whims of the Brains, who lays down the laws and decides how everything is run. (inspired by “The Marching Morons” by Cyril M. Kornbluth)

Gameplay Description:

One person plays as The Brain. The Brain’s objective is to survive by killing the Idiots with mind control – the player must concentrate, truly, to charge a weapon in order to shoot and kill one Idiot. This takes a couple of seconds, while the Idiots try to catch the Brain and ruin its concentration!

The Brain’s powers hinder the Idiots’ movement, so they are unusually sluggish creatures. This is because concentrated brain waves confuse the Idiots motive abilities, causing them to explode from confusion if they try to move too fast. However, if the Brain loses its concentration, the Idiots can move faster and converge on the Brain to catch it and steal its power.

If the Brain kills all Idiots, the Brain wins. If an Idiot catches the Brain (and devours the brain), the Idiots win.
Now that Idiot is the Brain and it all starts again!

fields.title: FLOT!
fields.short_credits: Game development: Patrick Jarnfelt, Sound: Anders Monrad, Anders Boerup, Graphics/Producer: Simon Nielsen
fields.short_description:
Flot! is a purely auditory physical game. The game is played by two players who take turns using their body to create sounds. The other player, having looked away during the sound creation, has only heard the audio and hasn’t seen the corresponding pose. The challenge for the second player, then, is to explore the soundscape using his body and match the sound and pose by ear only.

The players progress through various levels that all have different mapping of audio to the players’ motion and poses. Therefore, the core of the gameplay not only involves matching poses and audio, but freely exploring soundscapes with your body as well.

Flot! was created during the 48 hours of the Nordic Game Jam. The current state of the game is a proof of concept prototype. However, we feel that this kind of game has something novel to bring to the gaming field, and are eager to further develop and refine this concept.

fields.title: WHO TOOK THE APPLE?
fields.short_credits: Game Design: Lau Korsgaard, Visual Design: Simon Gustaffson, Special thanks: Marek Plichta, Ricky Haggett, Dajana Dimovska, Tim Garbos and everybody who playtested the game Saturday night during Nordic Game Jam
fields.short_description:
Who Took the Apple? is a 4 player card game played backwards in time! The game is played with an apple, a bucket, four beers and a set of large cards meant to be played on ground.

The objective of the game is to be the player who takes the apple, but the game is played backwards in time. The first card played will be the last action happening.

fields.title: MONKEY SEE MONKEY MIME
fields.short_credits: Game development:Patrick Jarnfelt, Sebbe Selvig, Game design: Lau Korsgaard, Douglas Wilson, Graphics: Simon Nielsen
fields.short_description:
Judged by their controller’s accelerometer, multiple players compete to mimic (mirror) a “conductor” player as best they can. Each player gets a turn to conduct. Highest total score wins. Act like a monkey, watch the conductor carefully, and be the first to mutate your avatar through the well-trodden path of human evolution – from primate to caveman to modern mime!

Our hope was to get players look at each other, rather than at the screen.

We debuted the game at our Killscreen vs. Scandinavia party at GDC 2011.

We’re still trying to figure out how best to develop/release the game. Send us your ideas!
